values.description:
This is the first of a series of cleanup changes.  These changes all involve either cleaning up the code, improving the test coverage, or both.  Some of the PRs are going to be large, and some small; I've tried to break it down to make it more digestible, but please let me know if I should break them down further.

* Start branch element-coverage-cleanup

* Sort header file includes in Element.

* Add in a new Element::Get method.

    This one is a little bit easier to use in that it returns
    just a boolean, and the value is stuffed into _param, a
    reference.  This comes out of the discussion here:
    #!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/333 .

    While I was in here, I ended up sharing more of the logic
    for ::Get so we have less duplicated code.  I also added
    tests for all of this.

* Remove the unimplemented PrintWiki method prototypes.

* Do a cleanup on all of Element.hh doxygen comments.

    It now at least has reasonable comments for everything.

* Add more tests to Element.cc.

    Along with this, combine some common code that was separated
    before.
values.title: Element coverage cleanup

summary.html:
This is the first of a series of cleanup changes. These changes all involve either cleaning up the code, improving the test coverage, or both. Some of the PRs are going to be large, and some small; I've tried to break it down to make it more digestible, but please let me know if I should break them down further.

  • Start branch element-coverage-cleanup

  • Sort header file includes in Element.

  • Add in a new Element::Get method.

    This one is a little bit easier to use in that it returns just a boolean, and the value is stuffed into _param, a reference. This comes out of the discussion here: #!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/333 .

    While I was in here, I ended up sharing more of the logic for ::Get so we have less duplicated code. I also added tests for all of this.

  • Remove the unimplemented PrintWiki method prototypes.

  • Do a cleanup on all of Element.hh doxygen comments.

    It now at least has reasonable comments for everything.

  • Add more tests to Element.cc.

    Along with this, combine some common code that was separated before.

values.description:
The preserveFixedJoint option is meant to disable the lumping
of fixed joints by "preserving" the type of a fixed joint,
instead of converting it to a revolute joint with max and min positions limits
set to 0 .

This PR is fully backcompatible: the old option `disableFixedJointLumping`  is still working fine, but if on the same joint both the new option `preserveFixedJoint` and the old option `disableFixedJointLumping` are present, then the joint will be converted to a fixed joint. This is meant to simplify the life of model creators that need to support both the old version of Gazebo (and hence sdformat) without support for  `preserveFixedJoint` and the new version that can exploit this new option. 

Targeting sdf4 (as discussed in #!/osrf/sdformat/issues/131/disabling-lumping-on-a-fixed-joint-in-a) but let me know if this is ok . Documentation for the URDF extensions is not versioned with the software, but is instead available at https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_tutorials . Once (and if) this PR is approve, I will provide the correct changes in the documentation. 


See #!/osrf/sdformat/issues/131/disabling-lumping-on-a-fixed-joint-in-a
values.title: Add preserveFixedJoint option to the URDF parser

summary.raw:
The preserveFixedJoint option is meant to disable the lumping
of fixed joints by "preserving" the type of a fixed joint,
instead of converting it to a revolute joint with max and min positions limits
set to 0 .

This PR is fully backcompatible: the old option `disableFixedJointLumping`  is still working fine, but if on the same joint both the new option `preserveFixedJoint` and the old option `disableFixedJointLumping` are present, then the joint will be converted to a fixed joint. This is meant to simplify the life of model creators that need to support both the old version of Gazebo (and hence sdformat) without support for  `preserveFixedJoint` and the new version that can exploit this new option. 

Targeting sdf4 (as discussed in #!/osrf/sdformat/issues/131/disabling-lumping-on-a-fixed-joint-in-a) but let me know if this is ok . Documentation for the URDF extensions is not versioned with the software, but is instead available at https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_tutorials . Once (and if) this PR is approve, I will provide the correct changes in the documentation. 


See #!/osrf/sdformat/issues/131/disabling-lumping-on-a-fixed-joint-in-a
summary.html:
The preserveFixedJoint option is meant to disable the lumping of fixed joints by "preserving" the type of a fixed joint, instead of converting it to a revolute joint with max and min positions limits set to 0 .

This PR is fully backcompatible: the old option disableFixedJointLumping is still working fine, but if on the same joint both the new option preserveFixedJoint and the old option disableFixedJointLumping are present, then the joint will be converted to a fixed joint. This is meant to simplify the life of model creators that need to support both the old version of Gazebo (and hence sdformat) without support for preserveFixedJoint and the new version that can exploit this new option.

Targeting sdf4 (as discussed in #!/osrf/sdformat/issues/131/disabling-lumping-on-a-fixed-joint-in-a) but let me know if this is ok . Documentation for the URDF extensions is not versioned with the software, but is instead available at https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_tutorials . Once (and if) this PR is approve, I will provide the correct changes in the documentation.

See #!/osrf/sdformat/issues/131/disabling-lumping-on-a-fixed-joint-in-a

values.description:
* Start branch exception-fixes

* Switch Exception to using a unique_ptr.

    This makes it consistent with most of the other classes.

* Switch to using cstdint in Exception.

    According to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13642827/cstdint-vs-stdint-h ,
    using cstdint should be preferred over using stdint.h.  The former puts
    things in the std:: namespace and optionally in the global namespace,
    while the latter puts things only in the global namespace.  Thus,
    in order to be maximally compliant with the spec and with namespaces,
    use cstdint and always refer to int64_t explicitly in the std::
    namespace.
values.title: Exception fixes

summary.raw:
* Start branch exception-fixes

* Switch Exception to using a unique_ptr.

    This makes it consistent with most of the other classes.

* Switch to using cstdint in Exception.

    According to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13642827/cstdint-vs-stdint-h ,
    using cstdint should be preferred over using stdint.h.  The former puts
    things in the std:: namespace and optionally in the global namespace,
    while the latter puts things only in the global namespace.  Thus,
    in order to be maximally compliant with the spec and with namespaces,
    use cstdint and always refer to int64_t explicitly in the std::
    namespace.
summary.html:
• Start branch exception-fixes

  • Switch Exception to using a unique_ptr.

    This makes it consistent with most of the other classes.

  • Switch to using cstdint in Exception.

    According to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13642827/cstdint-vs-stdint-h , using cstdint should be preferred over using stdint.h. The former puts things in the std:: namespace and optionally in the global namespace, while the latter puts things only in the global namespace. Thus, in order to be maximally compliant with the spec and with namespaces, use cstdint and always refer to int64_t explicitly in the std:: namespace.

values.description:
* Start branch param-fixes

* Switch to using cstdint in Param.

    According to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13642827/cstdint-vs-stdint-h ,
    using cstdint should be preferred over using stdint.h. The former puts things in
    the std:: namespace and optionally in the global namespace, while the latter
    puts things only in the global namespace. Thus, in order to be maximally
    compliant with the spec and with namespaces, use cstdint and always refer to
    int64_t explicitly in the std:: namespace.

* Add in a bunch more tests for Param.

    While we are in here, also fix a small bug in Set() that wouldn't
    always return an error.
values.title: Param fixes

summary.raw:
* Start branch param-fixes

* Switch to using cstdint in Param.

    According to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13642827/cstdint-vs-stdint-h ,
    using cstdint should be preferred over using stdint.h. The former puts things in
    the std:: namespace and optionally in the global namespace, while the latter
    puts things only in the global namespace. Thus, in order to be maximally
    compliant with the spec and with namespaces, use cstdint and always refer to
    int64_t explicitly in the std:: namespace.

* Add in a bunch more tests for Param.

summary.html:
• Start branch param-fixes

  • Switch to using cstdint in Param.

    According to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13642827/cstdint-vs-stdint-h , using cstdint should be preferred over using stdint.h. The former puts things in the std:: namespace and optionally in the global namespace, while the latter puts things only in the global namespace. Thus, in order to be maximally compliant with the spec and with namespaces, use cstdint and always refer to int64_t explicitly in the std:: namespace.

  • Add in a bunch more tests for Param.

    While we are in here, also fix a small bug in Set() that wouldn't always return an error.

values.description:
* Start branch readdir-conversion

* Change Unix DirIter next to use readdir instead of readdir_r.

    readdir is actually threadsafe on modern Unix, and readdir_r
    is depecated in very modern versions of Linux.  Thus, switch
    to using readdir exclusively.  Also mark it as NOLINT, since
    the linter doesn't yet know this fact.
values.title: Readdir conversion

summary.raw:
* Start branch readdir-conversion

* Change Unix DirIter next to use readdir instead of readdir_r.

    readdir is actually threadsafe on modern Unix, and readdir_r
    is depecated in very modern versions of Linux.  Thus, switch
    to using readdir exclusively.  Also mark it as NOLINT, since
    the linter doesn't yet know this fact.
summary.html:
• Start branch readdir-conversion

  • Change Unix DirIter next to use readdir instead of readdir_r.

    readdir is actually threadsafe on modern Unix, and readdir_r is depecated in very modern versions of Linux. Thus, switch to using readdir exclusively. Also mark it as NOLINT, since the linter doesn't yet know this fact.

values.description:
* Start branch parser-fixes

* Slightly improve performance in parser.cc

    When doing an initialization, don't go searching for the
    same file multiple times.  Just do it once and then use
    a common set of code for the rest of the machinery.

* Style cleanup in parser_urdf_TEST.cc

* Get rid of an unnecessary attribute.

* Fetch the URI data just once.

* Get rid of a duplicate findFile.

    Since "filename" is going to be passed into readDoc later,
    we don't need to do the findFile right now.

* Style cleanup in parser.cc

* Replace an open-coded "/" with filesystem::append.

* Only do the append for configFilePath once.

    Also, give better error messages when the model.config
    can't be found.
values.title: Parser fixes

summary.raw:
* Start branch parser-fixes

* Slightly improve performance in parser.cc

    When doing an initialization, don't go searching for the
    same file multiple times.  Just do it once and then use
    a common set of code for the rest of the machinery.

* Style cleanup in parser_urdf_TEST.cc

* Get rid of an unnecessary attribute.

* Fetch the URI data just once.

* Get rid of a duplicate findFile.

    Since "filename" is going to be passed into readDoc later,
    we don't need to do the findFile right now.

* Style cleanup in parser.cc

* Replace an open-coded "/" with filesystem::append.

* Only do the append for configFilePath once.

    Also, give better error messages when the model.config
    can't be found.
summary.html:
• Start branch parser-fixes

  • Slightly improve performance in parser.cc

    When doing an initialization, don't go searching for the same file multiple times. Just do it once and then use a common set of code for the rest of the machinery.

  • Style cleanup in parser_urdf_TEST.cc

  • Get rid of an unnecessary attribute.

  • Fetch the URI data just once.

  • Get rid of a duplicate findFile.

    Since "filename" is going to be passed into readDoc later, we don't need to do the findFile right now.

  • Style cleanup in parser.cc

  • Replace an open-coded "/" with filesystem::append.

  • Only do the append for configFilePath once.

    Also, give better error messages when the model.config can't be found.

values.description:
* Start branch use-fs-append-everywhere

* Make sure to use sdf::filesystem::append in all of tests.

    This makes it so that we use the preferred separator in all the
    tests.  While we are in here, we also fix up a bunch of
    includes, some style, and remove most of the suppressions in
    code_checks.sh that weren't being used.
values.title: Use fs append everywhere

summary.raw:
* Start branch use-fs-append-everywhere

* Make sure to use sdf::filesystem::append in all of tests.

    This makes it so that we use the preferred separator in all the
    tests.  While we are in here, we also fix up a bunch of
    includes, some style, and remove most of the suppressions in
    code_checks.sh that weren't being used.
summary.html:
• Start branch use-fs-append-everywhere

  • Make sure to use sdf::filesystem::append in all of tests.

    This makes it so that we use the preferred separator in all the tests. While we are in here, we also fix up a bunch of includes, some style, and remove most of the suppressions in code_checks.sh that weren't being used.

values.description:
I noticed some divergence of our cmake code on our various projects, and did a meld of ign-transport and sdformat and ported some fixes to ign-transport in [pull request 213](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/213/port-cmake-fixes-from-sdformat/diff?w=1) and found these improvements from ign-transport to port here:

* port fix to uninstall script for paths with spaces

* mark SSE cmake variables as advanced

* Check if compiler flags are valid instead of checking if Clang is in use

* add a space to string when comparing compiler names

* unfilter an extra flag on windows, fix logic for calling sdf_setup_apple() cmake logic

* whitespace and re-arrange some cmake code to match ign-transport
values.title: Port cmake fixes from ign-transport

summary.raw:
I noticed some divergence of our cmake code on our various projects, and did a meld of ign-transport and sdformat and ported some fixes to ign-transport in [pull request 213](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/213/port-cmake-fixes-from-sdformat/diff?w=1) and found these improvements from ign-transport to port here:

* port fix to uninstall script for paths with spaces

* mark SSE cmake variables as advanced

* Check if compiler flags are valid instead of checking if Clang is in use

* add a space to string when comparing compiler names

* unfilter an extra flag on windows, fix logic for calling sdf_setup_apple() cmake logic

* whitespace and re-arrange some cmake code to match ign-transport
summary.html:
I noticed some divergence of our cmake code on our various projects, and did a meld of ign-transport and sdformat and ported some fixes to ign-transport in pull request 213 and found these improvements from ign-transport to port here:

  • port fix to uninstall script for paths with spaces

  • mark SSE cmake variables as advanced

  • Check if compiler flags are valid instead of checking if Clang is in use

  • add a space to string when comparing compiler names

  • unfilter an extra flag on windows, fix logic for calling sdf_setup_apple() cmake logic

  • whitespace and re-arrange some cmake code to match ign-transport

values.description:
Backport of pull request #296 and pull request #345.

* Fix OS Specific initialization in CMakeLists.txt

* Fix for compiling with Visual Studio and vcpkg

    This commit contains two fixes:

    * The first one is to avoid the hardcoding
    of the location of the sdformat library (useful to avoid
    in multi-configuration CMake generators such as Visual Studio).

    * The second one modifies the logic of copying boost dll in the test
    directory to support the installation layout of boost when installed
    using vcpkg ( https://github.com/Microsoft/vcpkg ). The logic is still
    quite hardcoded, but at least now it does not fail to compile if the files
    are not found in the assumed location.
values.title: Backport Visual Studio 2015 fixes to sdf5

summary.raw:
Backport of pull request #296 and pull request #345.

* Fix OS Specific initialization in CMakeLists.txt

* Fix for compiling with Visual Studio and vcpkg

    This commit contains two fixes:

    * The first one is to avoid the hardcoding
    of the location of the sdformat library (useful to avoid
    in multi-configuration CMake generators such as Visual Studio).

    * The second one modifies the logic of copying boost dll in the test
    directory to support the installation layout of boost when installed
    using vcpkg ( https://github.com/Microsoft/vcpkg ). The logic is still
    quite hardcoded, but at least now it does not fail to compile if the files
    are not found in the assumed location.
summary.html:
Backport of pull request #296 and pull request #345.

  • Fix OS Specific initialization in CMakeLists.txt

  • Fix for compiling with Visual Studio and vcpkg

    This commit contains two fixes:

    • The first one is to avoid the hardcoding of the location of the sdformat library (useful to avoid in multi-configuration CMake generators such as Visual Studio).

    • The second one modifies the logic of copying boost dll in the test directory to support the installation layout of boost when installed using vcpkg ( https://github.com/Microsoft/vcpkg ). The logic is still quite hardcoded, but at least now it does not fail to compile if the files are not found in the assumed location.

values.description: See also pull request #367, and this has taken on added urgency due to a [recent cmake update](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/15764) that [broke sdformat on homebrew](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-sdformat4-homebrew-amd64/38/).
values.title: Backport fixes for Visual Studio 2015 to sdf4

summary.raw: See also pull request #367, and this has taken on added urgency due to a [recent cmake update](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/15764) that [broke sdformat on homebrew](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-sdformat4-homebrew-amd64/38/).
summary.html: See also pull request #367, and this has taken on added urgency due to a recent cmake update that broke sdformat on homebrew.

values.description: 9210183 adds an element for DART specific physics properties so that DART's LCP solver (Dantzig or PGS) can be specified. This property is useful because the Dantzig solver does not work for certain contact configurations (see [DART issue #892](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892)) while the PGS solver fails some integration tests (see [Gazebo PR #2755](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2755)).
values.title: DART specific physics properties

summary.raw: 9210183 adds an element for DART specific physics properties so that DART's LCP solver (Dantzig or PGS) can be specified. This property is useful because the Dantzig solver does not work for certain contact configurations (see [DART issue #892](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892)) while the PGS solver fails some integration tests (see [Gazebo PR #2755](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2755)).
summary.html: 9210183 adds an element for DART specific physics properties so that DART's LCP solver (Dantzig or PGS) can be specified. This property is useful because the Dantzig solver does not work for certain contact configurations (see DART issue #892) while the PGS solver fails some integration tests (see Gazebo PR #2755).

values.description:
I noticed some divergence of our cmake code on our various projects, and did a meld of ign-transport and sdformat and have found these improvements from ign-transport to port here:

* port fix to uninstall script for paths with spaces

* mark SSE cmake variables as advanced

* Check if compiler flags are valid instead of checking if Clang is in use

* add a space to string when comparing compiler names

* whitespace

* re-arrange some cmake code to match ign-transport and fix whitespace

* unfilter an extra flag on windows, fix logic for calling sdf_setup_apple() cmake logic

* remove duplicate cmake code

* set CXX flags not only on UNIX

similar to an ign-transport pull request:

* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/213/port-cmake-fixes-from-sdformat/diff

values.description: Added a function to wrap an SDF element around the root SDF element. This helper function is often needed. See also [gazebo pull request 2708](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2708)
values.title: Added wrapper around root SDF for an SDF element

summary.raw: Added a function to wrap an SDF element around the root SDF element. This helper function is often needed. See also [gazebo pull request 2708](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2708)
summary.html: Added a function to wrap an SDF element around the root SDF element. This helper function is often needed. See also gazebo pull request 2708

values.description:
Add support for attaching lights to links:

~~~
<model name="my_model">
  <link name="my_link">
    <light name="my_light" type="point">
        ...
    </light>
  </link>
</model>
~~~
values.title: Add light as child of link

summary.raw:
Add support for attaching lights to links:

~~~
<model name="my_model">
  <link name="my_link">
    <light name="my_light" type="point">
        ...
    </light>
  </link>
</model>
~~~
summary.html:
Add support for attaching lights to links:

<model name="my_model">
  <link name="my_link">
    <light name="my_light" type="point">
        ...
    </light>
  </link>
</model>

values.description: ~~Bumps the required version of ignition math to 4~~ Finds ignition math 3 if 4 is not available. This is necessary to build sdformat default branch against ignition-math default branch.
values.title: Depend on ignition math 3 or 4

summary.raw: ~~Bumps the required version of ignition math to 4~~ Finds ignition math 3 if 4 is not available. This is necessary to build sdformat default branch against ignition-math default branch.
summary.html: Bumps the required version of ignition math to 4 Finds ignition math 3 if 4 is not available. This is necessary to build sdformat default branch against ignition-math default branch.

values.description:
This is  the first step toward a document object model for SDF. The idea is to parse an SDF file into classes. There will be many more pull requests.

The example `dom` program can be run using:

`./dom <some SDF file>`
values.title: Part 1 of document object model

summary.raw:
This is  the first step toward a document object model for SDF. The idea is to parse an SDF file into classes. There will be many more pull requests.

The example `dom` program can be run using:

`./dom <some SDF file>`
summary.html:
This is the first step toward a document object model for SDF. The idea is to parse an SDF file into classes. There will be many more pull requests.

The example dom program can be run using:

./dom <some SDF file>

values.description:
1. Added support for math rendering in doxygen.

2. Added a World class to the DOM.

3. Improved error handling in the parser. The default behavior of the parser is still in place. There are now also function that return a vector of errors.
values.title: Dom part2

summary.raw:
1. Added support for math rendering in doxygen.

2. Added a World class to the DOM.

3. Improved error handling in the parser. The default behavior of the parser is still in place. There are now also function that return a vector of errors.
summary.html:
1. Added support for math rendering in doxygen.

  2. Added a World class to the DOM.

  3. Improved error handling in the parser. The default behavior of the parser is still in place. There are now also function that return a vector of errors.

values.title: Use math4 on pipelines for SDF6

values.description:
Use tinyxml2 instead of tinyxml. 

This change was based on the sdf5 branch. It would be nice to port to the default branch in a second step.

The build and tests were verified on linux. It would be nice if someone with a Windows and OSX machine could help to port the CMake files.
values.title: Port to tinyxml2

summary.raw:
Use tinyxml2 instead of tinyxml. 

This change was based on the sdf5 branch. It would be nice to port to the default branch in a second step.

The build and tests were verified on linux. It would be nice if someone with a Windows and OSX machine could help to port the CMake files.
summary.html:
Use tinyxml2 instead of tinyxml.

This change was based on the sdf5 branch. It would be nice to port to the default branch in a second step.

The build and tests were verified on linux. It would be nice if someone with a Windows and OSX machine could help to port the CMake files.
